Russian hackers are attacking critical U.S. infrastructure, including the energy grid, nuclear power plants, and airports, according to U.S. government officials.XWater processing plants are among the other targets being repeatedly tested by rolling attacks. Last year, more than a dozen power plants in seven states were breached due to Russia's ongoing campaign of cyberattacks.Energy Secretary Rick Perry told the House Appropriations Subcommittee Thursday cyberattacks are "literally happening hundreds of thousands of times a day. ... The warfare that goes on in the cyberspace is real, it's serious, and we must lead the world."Such attacks were cited as being one of the reasons the Trump administration imposed sanctions on a series of Russian organizations and individuals Thursday. In a doomsday scenario, such attacks could leave millions without water and electricity.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseUtility giant Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) was up 2.1% on the stock market today. Duke Energy (DUK) rose 1.1%, Sempra Energy (SRE) 0.7%, Edison International (EIX) 1.8% and Southern Co. (SO) 0.6%.An alert issued by the Department of Homeland Security and the FBI Thursday laid out in more detail what the Russians have been targeting, and how they are going about it."Since at least March 2016, Russian government cyber actors ... targeted government entities and multiple U.S. critical infrastructure sectors, including the energy, nuclear, commercial facilities, water, aviation, and critical manufacturing sectors," the alert said.The techniques being employed include sending spear-phishing emails from compromised legitimate accounts, host-based exploitation and the targeting of industrial control system infrastructure.Russian operatives are also using the hacks for credentials gathering and open-source and network reconnaissance.While the alert did not disclose how successful the attacks were, it said hackers "targeted small commercial facilities' networks where they staged malware, conducted spear phishing, and gained remote access into energy sector networks." They also tried to hide their activities by creating new accounts on the staging targets to perform cleanup operations.While information theft was one of the goals, a key prize would have been gaining control of systems used by infrastructure. They could then launch attacks that could leave millions without water and power.An even more worrying prospect would be hackers gaining control of a nuclear power plant. A sudden shutdown can trigger safety systems designed to disperse excess heat and prevent a meltdown, though safety systems themselves may be vulnerable to attack. However, the operating systems used at such plants are usually decades-old legacy controls that cannot be exploited by hackers.The Department of Homeland Security previously said cyberattacks on critical infrastructure are "one of the most serious national security challenges we must confront."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:As Trump Sanctions Putin's Russia, Will Dems Revert To Their Fallback Position — Appeasement? If a stock you're tracking clears a buy point then retreats 7% or more below the original entry price, it's considered a failed base. It's best to wait for the stock to form a new base and breakout. Also keep in mind that the most recent pattern is a later-stage base, and such bases are more prone to failure. Regarding top and bottom line numbers, the company has posted three quarters of accelerating earnings growth. Sales growth has been a different story, coming in at -3% last quarter. Stocks remained lower in afternoon trading Tuesday, as Coca-Cola's (KO) breakout to new highs reflected relative strength in consumer stocks.XThe Nasdaq composite tumbled 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Indexes bounced off early lows, but the selling resumed around 12.45 p.m. ET, leaving the Nasdaq near session lows.The Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.3% as General Electric (GE) continued its swoon, off 7%. Small caps faced new uncertainty after the Russell 2000 fell 0.6% and was not able to climb back above the 50-day moving average.Volume was tracking above the levels at the same time of day Monday.  Losers led winners by an 8-5 ratio across the board.Energy, telecom and metals stocks were some of the weakest in today's trading. Oil prices fell 2% to about $55 a barrel after a soft demand forecast from the International Energy Agency.In the IBD 50, Ichor Holdings (ICHR) was under stress. The stock slid right back below its 50-day moving average in heavy trading, one day after it seemed like it was finding support at that key level. An increase of more than 40% from buy points at 25.41 and 24.40 has nearly evaporated. The chip-equipment supplier's stock has been more volatile since it reported earnings Thursday.Hot IPO Roku (ROKU) reversed lower to a 5.5% loss in heavy trading. The stock had soared as much as 152% the past three days following the video-streaming device company's earnings.Consumer and defensive industry groups such as utilities and soft drinks were the best performing Tuesday.  Restaurants were up nearly 2% after Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) soared 25% on news that Roark Capital Group offered $2.3 billion to take the company private. Buffalo Wild Wings has been recovering from its lows in October but remains 16% below a 52-week high.In a sign of emerging strength in consumer plays, Dow component Coca-Cola broke out of a flat base, leaping past a 47.08 buy point in heavy volume.Wells Fargo upgraded the stock to outperform, and an analyst raised the possibility that Coke may enter the alcoholic-beverages market. Some details may be mentioned at Thursday's investor day, according to a CNBC report.Cantel Medical (CMD) jumped past its 99.93 buy point in a flat base, but volume was only about average. The maker of anti-infection and other medical products is making a presentation Wednesday at the Jefferies 2017 London Healthcare Conference.Pinnacle West Capital (PNW) broke out of a cup base, rising past a 91.02 buy point in flat volume. The holding company of electric utility Arizona Public Service is the latest in a handful of utility stocks that have broken out of bases in the past few weeks.The Dow utilities average was up 0.9%, leading the market.NRG Yield (NYLD), the alternative-energy and dividend-focused arm of NRG Energy (NRG), edged above a 20.10 buy point in light volume.RELATED:Buffalo Wild Wings Gets $2.3 Billion-Plus Buyout Bid From Roark Capital: WSJIchor Holdings Falls On In-Line Q3 Earnings Report

Key U.S. indexes were higher Friday as the Dow Jones industrial average knocked out another new high and extended its win streak to six.XPowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) led with a 0.3% gain, SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) gained 0.2% and SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) was up 0.1%. Emerging markets outperformed as iShares MSCI Emerging Markets (EEM) rose 0.4%.Among sector funds, chips, telecom and retail led the upside in the stock market today. But gold, energy and health care lagged.VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) and iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) advanced more than 1% each. Both are in buy range from their respective entries. Component stock Nvidia (NVDA) surged 6% as it broke out from a flat base. The graphics chipmaker is an IBD 50 stock.VanEck Vectors Junior Gold Miners (GDXJ) fell 1.4% and VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX) gave up 0.8%. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) and iShares Gold Trust (IAU) dipped about 0.4% apiece. Gold futures were down 0.6% to $1,320.90 an ounce.The Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at a fresh record high Thursday thanks to big gains from United Technologies (UTX), Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK), keeps on giving.It's produced a double-digit return this year and continues to offer new chances to buy. SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) climbed past a 221.78 flat-base entry Thursday and remains in buy range. It last set up a buy opportunity on a rebound off the 50-day moving average in mid-August, right about the time it was featured in this ETF column.Shares have now advanced nearly 3% from that bounce off that line. And back in early June, it broke out past a 211.69 flat-base buy point and rose 5% to an Aug. 8 high.The $17.6 billion ETF, which tracks the price-weighted blue chip index, will mark its 20th anniversary in January. Biggest holdings as of Sept. 12 included Boeing (BA), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL), according to Morningstar Direct. The top five names accounted for 32% of assets.DIA's year-to-date return of 14% as of Sept. 13 is just ahead of the S&P 500's 13.3% gain. Over the long haul, the fund's performance is roughly in line with the benchmark index. For instance, DIA and the S&P 500 have both posted a 9.3% average annual return over the past 15 years. QQQ carries a 0.17% expense ratio.IBD'S TAKE: Boeing is near all-time highs, but is it worthy of your watch list? Find out if it's one of the top-rated stocks in its industry group at IBD Stock Checkup.Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP) is shaping the right side of a flat base and getting close to a 94.90 buy point. The $13.6 billion fund was spotlighted in the June 26 ETF column as it held in buy range from an earlier breakout. It climbed 2% from that entry to the left-side high of the current pattern.The $13.6 billion fund, launched in April 2013, tracks the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index Total Return. As the name indicates, it's much more diversified than DIA. The biggest sector weightings as of Sept. 11 were consumer cyclical, financial services, industrials, health care and technology, in that order. Top holdings included NRG Energy (NRG), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and Ralph Lauren (RL).RSP's 10% YTD return lags the S&P 500, but it leads over the past 10 years with an 8.5% average annual return vs. the benchmark index's 7.7% gain. The ETF bears a 0.20% expense ratio.One of Thursday's picks, iShares Edge MSCI Multifactor USA (LRGF), took out a 29.58 buy point and is still in buy range. PowerShares Russell 1000 Equal Weight Portfolio (EQAL) is still trading just below a 29.37 entry.RELATED:Dow Leads As These 2 Big Names Gain; 2 Equity Plays Setting UpApple Among Dow's Top Losers; Which Dow Stock Is In Buy Range?Apple Gains As Launch Event Kicks Off; 2 Dividend Plays To Watch

Key U.S. index funds were mixed midday Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average leading on big gains from Boeing (BA) and Pfizer (PFE).XSPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) was up 0.1%, while SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) was flat and PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) was down 0.2%.Energy, gold and telecom were among the biggest gainers in the stock market today. Retail, biotech and homebuilders underperformed.VanEck Vectors Oil Services (OIH) and SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production (XOP) surged about 2% each as West Texas intermediate crude prices rose 2% to $50.25 a barrel. United States Oil (USO) and PowerShares DB Oil (DBO) gained 1.2% and 0.9%, respectively.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) and iShares Gold Trust (IAU) climbed 0.2% apiece. Gold futures were slightly higher at $1,329.30 an ounce.The stock market has been setting up more potential buy opportunities as it rises into record high territory.PowerShares Russell 1000 Equal Weight Portfolio (EQAL) is building the right side of a flat base with a potential buy point at 29.37. It closed Wednesday less than 1% below the entry. Two prior flat-base breakouts in June and January yielded respective gains of 2% and 3%.The $296.1 million fund, which tracks the Russell 1000 Equal Weight Index, was launched in December 2014. The index is equally weighted across nine sector groups, with stocks within each sector also equally weighted. The fund and index get rebalanced on a quarterly basis. The traditional market-cap-weighted approach gives more clout to bigger-cap stocks, while equal weight may help limit the impact of a single stock.EQAL's biggest sector weightings as of Sept. 12 are information technology at 14%, industrials 12%, health care 11.5%, and consumer staples and energy accounting for just under 11% each. Top holdings included DowDuPont (DWDP), NRG Energy (NRG) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) at a respective 0.34%, 0.31% and 0.26% of assets.The fund's year-to-date return of 8.9% through Sept. 12 lags the S&P 500's 13.1% gain, according to Morningstar Direct. EQAL caries a 0.20% expense ratio.Let's revisit iShares Edge MSCI Multifactor USA (LRGF), which was featured in the May 30 ETF column as the fund was poised to break out from a flat base. It cleared the buy point June 1 and advanced nearly 3% before pausing to form its current flat-base pattern. LRGF closed Wednesday a nickel shy of a 29.58 entry.IBD'S TAKE: Applied Materials is a hot chipmaker, but is it worthy of your watch list? Find out if it's one of the top-rated stocks in its industry group at IBD Stock Checkup.The $565.5 million fund, launched in April 2015, is a bit younger than EQAL. LRGF tracks the MSCI USA Diversified Multiple-Factor Index, which  focuses on financially healthy firms, stocks that are inexpensive, smaller companies and trending stocks, according to iShares' website.Information technology accounted for the biggest sector weighting at about 19%, financials made up 15%, health care 13% and industrials 10%. Top holdings included AT&T (T), Accenture (ACN), General Motors (GM) and Applied Materials (AMAT).LRGF trails the S&P 500 with a YTD gain of 11.5% vs. the benchmark index's 13.1% return. It's outpaced the S&P 500 over the past year with a 20.1% vs. 18.1% gain. The expense ratio is 0.20%.Wednesday's picks, Materials Select Sector SPDR (XLB) and Vanguard Materials Index Fund (VAW), both eased slightly but remain in buy range from their respective flat-base buy points.RELATED:Apple Among Dow's Top Losers; Which Dow Stock Is In Buy Range?Apple Gains As Launch Event Kicks Off; 2 Dividend Plays To Watch2 Hot Biotech Plays In Reach, But Is Apple Still In Buy Range?

U.S. stock indexes traded nearly flat midday Thursday, as Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen testified before Congress for a second day.X The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1% each, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The small cap Russell 2000 stepped down 0.4%. Volume in the stock market today was down on both major exchanges.Yellen's remarks appeared to be adjustment from Wednesday's emphasis. Some market-watchers regarded Yellen's remarks Wednesday as signaling a slower approach on rate hikes. But Yellen said Thursday that she saw risks on inflation being "two-sided." Inflation could be too high or too low, she said.Blue chips were about evenly split among winners and losers. Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) rang up the best gain in the Dow Jones industrial average, rising 1.5% in modestly higher volume. The stock is below its 50-day line but above the 200-day line.Apple (AAPL) rose 0.7% in average volume. Apple is in the same situation as Wal-Mart — above the 200-day but below the 50-day line. However, Apple is heading toward its fifth daily gain in a row and is only 2% below its 50-day.Watch to see if Apple can retake the line and hold above it. If Apple can build the right side of its current consolidation, the result could be a rather oddly shaped flat base. The base would only be stage two. As a stock rises, it pauses to consolidate. Breakouts from a first- or second-stage base are more likely to work than those from later-stage bases.In the S&P 500, NRG Energy (NRG) gapped up for a second consecutive day. The utility stock advanced 29% Wednesday and an additional 9% Thursday morning.The company recently announced that it would sell assets and lower debt as part of a company transformation.Stock groups moving up were mostly beaten-down stocks. The Retail-Department Stores group rose 3%. Retail/Wholesale-Auto Parts added 2%. Retail apparel tacked on 1%.On the downside, gold miners and medical groups, including biotechs, fell the most.RELATED:Morgan Stanley Raises Price Target For NetflixJ.C. Penney Toys With New StrategyHere's One Reason Why Apple's Run May Not Be Over

A wobbly week turned solid Wednesday as comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen gave markets some predictability on which to bank, sending a broad range of industries higher and many leading stocks to new highs.The Nasdaq paced out a nice lead, ending ahead 1.1%, with Activision Blizzard (ATVI) leading the charge. The video game maker surged 5%, ending extended after a rebound from support at its 10-week moving average.The S&P 500 rattled off a 0.7% win, spearheaded by NRG Energy (NRG), which spiked 29% after announcing an extensive restructuring plan, to include $4 billion in asset sales.The Dow Jones industrial average ended ahead 0.6%, led by DuPont's (DD) 3% gain. JPMorgan (JPM) posted the Dow's sole decline, down 0.3% after Yellen declared interest rate hikes were likely to remain modest.Shares in solar energy, computer software and gaming were among the session's top performers. Airlines, foreign banks and auto dealers also turned in strong advances.Only 25 of 197 industry group posted losses for the day, with dairy products, building products and farm equipment all near the bottom of the list.Nasdaq 100 and IBD 50 name PayPal (PYPL) rose 3% to 56.55 as the stock cleared a flat base with a 55.25 buy point. The strength was fueled by news that Apple (AAPL) now accepts PayPal at its iTunes store.Also in the IBD 50, Sina (SINA) jumped 5% to 92.22 as it carves a flat base with a 97.79 buy point. Sina owns a stake in Weibo (WB), which rose 5%. Weibo is back above the 50-day moving average as it works on a potential base.RELATED:Facebook Hits Record High As Snap Falls; Twitter Signals ReboundSecond Payment Stock Breaks Out, This Time On Apple Deal

Stocks rode through Wednesday's closing bell with moderate gains, buoyed by the release of minutes showing the Fed bullish on a possible rate hike in June.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each added 0.4%. The S&P 500 rose more than 0.2% and made a new closing high. Preliminary data showed volume was higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq than at the end of trade Tuesday.Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's May 2-3 meeting showed the Fed remained supportive of an increase in the key interest rate at its June meeting, which would mark the second rate hike this year and the third since December. The minutes also showed the committee considering to begin winding down the Fed's $4.5 trillion stockpile of bond holdings amassed in its monetary stimulus, but probably not until later in the year — a reprieve for those who had begun expecting some action as early as September.Investors liked what they heard, sending the S&P 500, the Dow and the Nasdaq sharply higher just after the release. That left the S&P 500 a breath below its prior high of 2405 set May 16. The Nasdaq and the Dow also held below their prior peaks.Goldman Sachs (GS) surged 2% to lead the Dow industrials. General Electric (GE) dropped 1.6% after Chief Executive Jeff Immelt said the company would need to cut deeper into costs to meet targets in its ambitious restructuring. Goldman Sachs rose close to its 10-week moving average. GE's loss snuffed a four-day bounce from a 52-week low.Financial software brand Intuit (INTU) easily topped the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 7% after strong fiscal third-quarter results late Tuesday. The gap-up left shares extended above buy points of 127.74 and 128.55.Clinching the No. 2 and No. 3 slots on the S&P 500 were utilities NRG (NRG) and AES (AES), up 5.5% and 3%, respectively. Rallying utilities sometimes signal a defensive shift among institutional investors.Jewelers took some of the day's hardest hits. Tiffany (TIF) suffered a 9% drop after delivering mixed first-quarter results. Signet Jewelers (SIG), scheduled to report first-quarter results before Thursday's open, tanked 7%.Aircraft components maker Triumph Group (TGI) spiked 30.5% after a big fiscal fourth-quarter earnings beat, although full-year revenue guidance was below the consensus view. The gain hoisted shares back above the stock's 10- and 40-week moving averages, ending 62% above an early-May low.Among IBD 50 stock's, Stamps.com (STMP) rallied 5% to close within 3% of a 136.10 buy point in a cup base. As Super Bowl LI takes its place in the history books — climaxing with a 34-28 victory by the Tom Brady-led New England Patriots over the feisty Atlanta Falcons, settled abruptly in overtime as the Patriots notched the biggest come-from-behind rally in the NFL championship game's annals — the Patriots and the Falcons probably were not the only teams you had a rooting interest in. Through mutual funds in which you are a shareholder, you likely had a financial stake in the annual sports and advertising extravaganza.More than 10,000 mutual funds hold shares in at least six companies that ran television ads during the game in NRG Stadium in Houston, which was expected to be watched by more than 100 million viewers. The ranks of those funds include some of the biggest names in the industry. That puts the odds in your favor that a slice of your portfolio may gain value, depending on the impact of ads during the game. The odds go up that your portfolio will be impacted when the pool of mutual funds is expanded to account for ads before and after the game as well, and game-related ads in additional media.Advertisers ranged from the very familiar such as Budweiser beer, whose parent company is Anheuser Busch InBev (BUD), and carmaker Mercedes-Benz, owned by Daimler (DDAIF), to lesser-known enterprise software company Wix.com (WIX).IBD'S TAKE: IBD reported Thursday that German automaker Daimler said that its fourth-quarter net profit rose 18%, but the firm offered only modest guidance for future earnings as it gets ready to spend on new models and advanced technologies such as autonomous driving.InBev shares were down 16% over the past 12 months, going into Friday. But Daimler was up 8% in that period. And Wix shares had soared 159%.Mutual funds owning a piece of advertisers in the big game included $104 billion Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX), $82.2 billion American Funds Investment Company of America (AIVSX), $40.9 billion MFS Value (MEIAX), $16.7 billion T. Rowe Price New Horizons (PRNHX), $13.1 billion JPMorgan U.S. Equity (JUEAX), $12 billion Franklin Growth (FKGRX) and $8.5 billion Hartford Capital Appreciation (ITHAX).Other funds with players in the ad contest: $7.5 billion MFS Total Return (MSFRX), $6.8 billion Vanguard Total International Stock Index (VGTSX), $5.7 billion ClearBridge Large Cap Growth (SBLGX), $4.8 billion Goldman Sachs Mid Cap Value (GCMAX), $4.6 billion AMG Yacktman Focused (YAFFX) and $3.3 billion Alger Capital Appreciation (ALARX).Those funds are among the stock owners in six publicly traded companies that advertised on TV during the Super Bowl: Budweiser, Intel (INTC), Mercedes-Benz, Mountain Dew (PEP), Victoria's Secret (LB) and Wix.com.Intel shares are up 23% over the past 12 months. The stock has a decent 82 Composite Rating from IBD. The Composite Rating, which starts at 1 and runs to 99, combines IBD's five performance ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a Comp Rating of 95 or higher.PepsiCo shares are up 6% in the past year. Performing dismally, L Brands stock is down 38% in the past year.Altogether, 10,898 mutual funds held stakes in those six companies or their corporate parents as of Dec. 31. Their positions in the six amounted to 2.49 billion shares.Mutual funds held just 1.3% of total shares in Budweiser owner Anheuser Busch InBev. Mutual funds owned 40.7% of Wix.com, an Israeli company that offers customers a web development platform.Mutual funds held 39.1% of the shares in Victoria's Secret parent L Brands, 34.8% of Intel, 31.7% of Mountain Dew parent PepsiCo and 26.6% of Mercedes driver Daimler's ADRs.Additional publicly traded TV advertisers during the game included Ford (F) and Volkswagen (VLKAY)-owned Audi and Kia.RELATED:Where Mutual Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stock Gains In 20172017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market Review

“Revolutionary.” “State of the art.” That was how President Obama described what would become the Ivanpah solar power plant in the Mojave Desert in a 2010 radio address.When Ivanpah started operations in 2014, the Department of Energy hailed its “innovative power-tower technology” and credited $1.6 billion in federal subsidized loans — as well as hundreds of millions in tax credits — for making the 4,000-acre solar plant a reality.It’s been pretty much downhill for Ivanpah ever since.The latest problem for the plant — which is owned by BrightSource Energy Inc., NRG Energy (NRG) and Alphabet Inc.’s Google (GOOGL) -- came last week when it literally set itself on fire.Unlike other solar power facilities, that use photovoltaic panels, Ivanpah relies on 173,500 computer-controlled mirrors that focus the sun’s heat onto water tanks atop three 452-feet tall towers. The heat boils the water, and the steam turns the turbines.Turns out, some of those mirrors got misaligned, and pointing their heat rays too low, setting one of the towers on fire on Friday, which forced the tower to shut down.Embarrassing as this is, it is arguably the least of Ivanpah’s problems.Back in March, the plant faced the possibility of being shut down because it wasn’t delivering enough electricity to PG&E (PGC) as contracted. Ivanpah operated at about 45% of promised capacity in 2015 and 67% last year.California’s Public Utilities Commission decided to give the plant another year to meet is contractual obligations to the utility. But even then, the cost of electricity produced by Ivanpah is much higher than that from natural gas or even photovoltaic solar systems.Not only has Ivanpah turned out to be far more expensive than other sources of energy, but it's less green than advertised.Last summer, PG&E paid close to $200 per megawatt-hour for electricity from the plant, at a time when natural gas-powered plants cost about $35 a megawatt-hour.And because it depends on natural gas to preheat the boilers, Ivanpah emits 46,000 tons of CO2 a year, enough to require the plant to participate in California’s carbon cap-and-trade program.So, what we have is a power plant that can’t meet its quota for energy production, that relies on conventional sources of energy to operate, that can set itself on fire, and that is far more costly than other sources of electricity, and that is sucking up taxpayer dollars in the process.This isn't revolutionary. This is just a classic example of industrial policy at work.RELATEDEnvironmentalists Fight Huge Solar Plant On Behalf of 100 SheepMassive Solar Power Plant Emits 46,000 Tons of CO2The Dark Side Of Solar Power

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) head Warren Buffett, Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg and Alphabet (GOOGL) Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt were among the dozens of business leaders announcing Thursday their endorsement for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton."Trump would destroy much of what is great about America," said Netflix (NFLX) CEO Reed Hastings in a statement released by the Clinton camp that includes the full list of endorsements. "Hillary Clinton is the strong leader we need, and it's important that Trump lose by a landslide to reject what he stands for."Also on the list are Delta Air Lines (DAL) Executive Chairman Richard Anderson, Salesforce (CRM) CEO Marc Benioff, Sunrun (RUN) CEO Lynn Jurich and Qualcomm (QCOM) Executive Chairman Paul Jacobs.Some are switching party allegiances to vote for Clinton, including General Motors' (GM) former chairman and CEO Dan Akerson and AT&T (T) Services senior executive vice president Jim Cicconi."Serving as the leader of the free world requires effective leadership, sound judgment, a steady hand and most importantly, the temperament to deal with crises large and small," said Akerson in the statement, who has "consistently" voted for Republicans for president. "Donald Trump lacks each of these characteristics. Hillary Clinton has the experience and judgment to serve as an effective commander in chief. In this election, I will cast my ballot for Secretary Clinton."Meanwhile, Continental Resources (CLR) CEO Harold Hamm, Home Depot (HD) co-founder Bernard Marcus and Facebook board member and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among those in the business world supporting Donald Trump's run for presidency.The full list of those announcing Clinton endorsements, as published on her campaign site, is as follows:

Lots of stocks on Your Weekly Review are near buy points, but after filtering out those in late-stage bases and companies with mediocre earnings growth, few are left.The ones that pass the tests are worth further consideration. So here are five leading stocks whose earnings in the latest quarter topped 25% and whose bases are first- or second-stage:Monarch Casino & Resort (MCRI) is forming a cup-with-handle base with a buy point at 21.01. Its base undercut an August-October base, which reset the base count.The stock dropped out of this week's Weekly Review.Monarch, which operates casinos in Reno, Nev., and Black Hawk, Colo., is lagging other casino leading stocks such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS), which have properties in the fast-growing Macau gambling area of China.Electronics for Imaging (EFII) is breaking out of a flat base. Shares this week topped the 39.97 buy point in heavy trading, but a reversal Wednesday sent shares back below the buy point. The stock, though, is near the entry.The maker of specialized printers and printer technologies posted accelerating earnings gains of 10%, 27% and 39% in the most recent quarters. Analysts expect a modest 5% EPS gain for the fourth quarter, however.NRG Yield (NYLD) is finding support at the 10-week moving average and may be forming a base-on-base pattern. The alternative-energy company has an EPS Rating of 99.Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS) is forming a flat base with a potential entry at 171.10.The financial services provider notched a Q3 earnings gain of 31% as revenue increased 46%.BofI Holding (BOFI) is shaping a flat base with a buy point at 82.37. Technically the stock is in a first-stage base, but it has made a major advance since 2012.The online banking firm recorded a 27% increase in profit in the September-ended quarter.

No. 2 residential installer Sunrun (RUN) could fortify against top rival SolarCity (SCTY) by acquiring NRG Energy's (NRG) rooftop business, a Credit Suisse analyst suggested Monday. But both Sunrun and SolarCity stocks were torched by the analyst's estimate cuts.On the stock market today, SolarCity stock fell 2.5%, but Sunrun stock, down as much as 4.9% early, ended up 1.1%, at 7.97.SolarCity and Sunrun are slated to report Q1 earnings on May 9 and May 12, respectively. Installations appear to be tracking in line, but bookings are below guidance and will likely jeopardize the companies' respective 44% and 40% growth guidance, said Credit Suisse analyst Patrick Jobin.Jobin cut his price targets on SolarCity and Sunrun stocks to 62 from 89, and to 18 from 21, respectively. In a research note, Jobin said he expects SolarCity to have installed 178 megawatts in Q1, up 18% year over year, vs. guidance for 180 MW."We believe we are being very conservative, a necessary measure as the company has missed guidance (in) three of the last five quarters," he wrote.Jobin expects Sunrun to hit installation views for 56 MW, down 18% vs. the previous quarter, on the exclusion of 12 MW in Nevada. Nevada recently cut payments to solar customers for energy fed back into the grid, and it retroactively applied the new rules to existing customers, prodding solar companies to exit the state.That Nevada net-metering decision, complicated by "regulatory flux" -- California and Massachusetts' rule-making and the Investment Tax Credit extension -- is the likely culprit behind slow Q1 bookings, Jobin wrote.For Q1, the consensus of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters tips SolarCity to report $108.5 million in sales, up 61% year over year, and a $2.34 per-share loss minus items, widening from a $1.52 loss in the year-earlier quarter.Three months ago, SolarCity guided to a $2.55-$2.65 per-share loss minus items.Sunrun is expected to report $83.4 million in sales and a 53-cent per-share loss minus items. Sales would fall 16% from Q4, and losses would deepen from a 15-cent loss in the prior quarter. Sunrun made its IPO last August.Jobin cut his U.S. 2016 residential demand to 3 gigawatts, up 45%. Of that, he expects SolarCity to install 1.2 GW, and Sunrun to install 271 MW.NRG could prove a wildcard, Jobin said. A deal with Sunrun would make sense, given the firm's platform model."NRG's residential business has been earmarked for a change -- potentially an imminent sale or partnership," he wrote. "Whatever happens will be critical, as it could enable a weaker player or strengthen an incumbent."

Stocks took a broad step higher Friday, giving the Nasdaq a narrow gap above its 200-day moving average.The S&P 500, Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq climbed 0.8% each. Small-caps outpaced the general market, sending the Russell 2000 ahead 1.2%.The stock market today wrestled with mixed trade. Volume rose 7% on the NYSE, relative to action at the same time Thursday. But the Nasdaq's advance came in weak support, with volume slipping 7% below Thursday's morning levels.In economic news, the Commerce Department reported businesses saw wholesale inventories contract 0.5% in February. That was a faster decline than the 0.2% slip seen in January, and worse than the 0.2% decline expected by economist consensus.Oil futures accelerated their early advance, with West Texas intermediate surging more than 5% to above $39 a barrel. Prices may see some impact from the Baker Hughes (BHI) weekly rig count, due out at 1 p.m. ET.NRG Energy (NRG), Murphy Oil (MUR) and Chesapeake (CHK) were early gainers in the S&P 500.Nearly a third of the Dow stocks posted gains above 1%. American Express (AXP) topped the group with a 1.7% advance.NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) popped almost 3% to lead the Nasdaq 100. News reports said the Netherlands-based chipmaker was considering a sale of its standard products business, possibly to a Chinese buyer. Other chipmakers also boosted the Nasdaq, with Micron Technologies (MU) and Qualcomm (QCOM) each rising nearly 2%.Retail stocks were in motion, both good and bad.IBD 50 stock Ulta Beauty (ULTA) cracked a new high, jumping almost 4% in powerful trade. That put the stock out of buy range, more than 6% above a 188.58 cup base buy point. Ulta announced late Thursday it joins the S&P 500 index after the close of trade April 15.Gap (GPS) crumbled 11% in early trade. The apparel retailer reported late Thursday its March same-store-sales fell 6% compared with a 2% gain a year ago. Sales have now declined for 12 straight months. The loss put shares down 17% for the week. Nordstom (JWN) appeared to catch some of the downdraft, falling 4% in heavy trade.

Bankruptcy clouds shadow SunEdison (SUNE) this week, ahead of a Wednesday deadline to file its annual 10-K or, say analysts, default on $725 million in second-lien loans -- an inferno, at least two analyst say, that ties back to its yieldcos TerraForm Power (TERP) and TerraForm Global (GLBL).Late Tuesday, reports surfaced that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission might be probing SunEdison's liquidity stance. The Wall Street Journal reported that SEC investigators are examining how much cash SunEd had on hand last year.SunEdison stock plunged 55% in the stock market today on the investigation rumor, dipping to an all-time low below 1."I'd say (SunEdison is) kind of on life support as we speak," S&P Global Market Intelligence analyst Angelo Zino told IBD on Monday. "We have absolutely no visibility into the financial outlook of the company. It's obviously very worrisome."SunEdison last held an earnings call in November, about two weeks before it fired Carlos Domenech, SunEd executive vice president and CEO of both TerraForms. According to TerraForm Power's proxy statement, Domenech first initiated communications with Vivint Solar (VSLR).On July 20, SunEdison announced its plan to acquire residential solar installer Vivint. The deal briefly got a warm embrace on Wall Street, but shares of SunEdison and Vivint Solar have plummeted a respective 98% and 84% since then. In December, SunEd cut its bid on Vivint to reflect the drop in stock price, and this month Vivint scrapped its sale to SunEdison, citing financial concerns about the acquirer. A major TerraForm Power investor had been angling to block the deal as well. The transaction would have dropped Vivint Solar's 523-megawatt rooftop assets down to TerraForm Power.Since then, SunEdison delayed its annual 10-K financial statement on Feb. 29 and March 16, citing an ongoing investigation into its liquidity stance. The investigation arose from allegations by former and current executives of financial misconduct.Yield company TerraForm Power blamed SunEd for its own late 10-K. TerraForm Power is facing Nasdaq delisting as well as a potential slew of investor class action lawsuits related to the insider trading and fraud portions of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. TerraForm Power stock, down 8% early Tuesday, rallied to rise 1.7%, to 8.61.Zino maintains his hold rating on SunEdison stock, but over the past week investment banks Cowen and Stifel Nicolaus have dropped their coverage on SunEdison stock.Nine months ago, SunEdison was a different company, Zino says. In June, SunEdison's assets were valuable, the company had ready access to the debt financing and equity markets, and could tap its healthy TerraForm yieldcos. A yieldco is created to house assets, generate on-tap cash flow and yield tax-free dividends. TerraForm Power filed its IPO in June 2014. NRG Energy (NRG) followed in May 2015 with a superior strategy, T-Rex Group CEO Benjamin Cohen told IBD.T-Rex Group is an analytics-based advisory group for renewable stocks. NRG Yield (NYLD) held 71% non-renewable assets in conjunction with 29% renewable assets -- balancing older profitable assets with newer and more quickly-depreciating renewable assets.By appearing less profitable overall, the yieldco can pay less in taxes, Cohen explained. It's a completely legal strategy -- and investors ate it up. Soon, the yieldcos were producing more cash than the parent company could invest."So they had to invest in unsecured assets," namely the pre-development stages of projects already dropped into the yieldcos. "They were overpaying for assets . . . and that risk drove up the price of the assets."The bubble burst.Days after announcing its plan to acquire Vivint Solar, SunEdison's TerraForm Global filed its IPO and launched on Wall Street at 12.44, 17% below its 15 IPO price. Shares dove 19% Tuesday, to 2.03.SunEdison may be the "public poster child" for the yieldco bubble burst, but SunEd's downfall isn't indicative of the broader solar market and asset class, Cohen says."This is the failure of a capital market vehicle, as opposed to the failure of an asset class or the failure of one particular company," he said. But, he acknowledged, SunEd was slugged particularly hard in the yieldco blast and investors are leery of ongoing financial storms."Equity investors are discounting the value of SunEdison because management hasn't proved its ability to execute on its strategy," he said. "It seems overdone."NRG Yield stock is down nearly 50% since its peak near 28 last June. The First Solar (FSLR)-SunPower (SPWR) jointly-owned yieldco, 8point3 Energy Partners (CAFD), went public last June at 21 and closed Tuesday at 14.27, down 1.2%.July 20 proved to be SunEdison stock's recent high point, at 33.45. Shares have traded around 1 since February.SunEdison was targeting aggressive growth via M&A and aiming to use yieldcos TerraForm Power and TerraForm Global to help pay for its investments, Zino says. Debt financing was available but more difficult, he says, considering SunEd's heavily-leveraged balance sheet.Investors worried that SunEdison's Vivint Solar acquisition was too much, too fast. Then, TerraForm Global opened far below its IPO price."The fact SunEdison didn't have a fallback, the fact they were getting too aggressive with these M&A deals was part of the reason we saw the investment community sell off on these yieldco vehicles," Zino said.He added: "Once they weren't able to tap the yieldcos anymore, that's what really put SunEdison in the situation it's in today."Now, SunEdison is struggling to shop its assets around to third-party developers. In June, SunEd's yieldcos would have bought those assets. Not now. And lacking newer financial statements, no bank will touch SunEd, Zino said."Until they are able to get a resolution to the 10-K filing, we wouldn't expect to see anything come out of the debt market, and it becomes problematic for the third-party market as well," he said. "It becomes difficult for utilities to invest in SunEdison if they have no idea of the type of financial situation SunEdison is in."And SunEd certainly can't tap the equity market.Said Zino, "a precipitous decline in the yieldco prices had a direct impact on SunEdison stock and, as a result, we saw billions and billions (of dollars) in equity value wiped out from the yieldcos and SunEdison together."

This week marked an important anniversary: The current bull market is now seven years old. That's many, many moons of watching stock indexes march higher and pocketing sizable returns on your hard-earned investments.Caution returned to the market in 2015, as the S&P 500 started to trade sideways. Stocks are taking a bit of a breather this year too. Perhaps you're in need of one too.So take a moment to catch up on ETF winners of the current bull market. As the table below shows, they span a host of asset classes, from financials and preferred stocks to retail and midcaps.The very top performer out of 1,646 nonleveraged ETFs is -- are you ready for this? -- Guggenheim S&P 500 Pure Value (RPV), an ETF that targets the cheapest third of the S&P 500 index.A bull market brings to mind higher beta positions, with a stronger growth skew. Yet in the past seven years, the market has rewarded value-oriented characteristics slightly more so than growth, said Guggenheim managing director William Belden. That's helped RPV outperform.Value ETFs are generally considered to perform well over longer periods of time. "Their greatest appeal is when the markets have gone both ways," Belden said.A closer look at RPV may be timely, as the market seems to have arrived at an inflection point for value stocks.RPV produced an average annual 30% return from March 10, 2009, to March 9, 2016. By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) gained an annualized 19% over the same period.SPY was also outpaced by Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP), with an annual average return of 22.4%.For investors seeking to make a style-focused bet on the markets, six Guggenheim ETFs offer style purity. They invest in only those stocks in the S&P 500, S&P MidCap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600 with the strongest value and growth characteristics.Traditional cap-weighted growth or value indexes generally have some overlap between growth and value stocks.Guggenheim's "Pure Style ETFs" avoid the muddle in the middle, as Belden likes to say. They also weight stocks by the strength of their growth or value characteristics.With $693.9 million in assets, RPV holds a mere 111 stocks from the S&P 500. They're selected based on metrics such as price-to-book, price-to-sales and price-to-earnings ratios.Top holdings now include electricity supplier NRG Energy (NRG), tech business HP Inc. (HPQ) and seeds processor Archer Daniels Midland (ADM).Morningstar analyst Alex Bryan cautions that this is a risky ETF investing strategy."The S&P 500 Pure Value Index was about 47% more volatile than the market-cap-weighted S&P 500 Value Index, which tracks the cheaper half of the S&P 500, during the past decade," he wrote in October 2015. "It has also tended to underperform during market downturns."Belden points out RPV has rewarded investors willing to take on a little higher volatility."It has a good risk-adjusted profile," he said. The expense ratio is 0.35%.Most investors tend to combine RPV with an S&P 500 ETF such as SPY to overweight value stocks. But RPV can also be combined with its sibling Guggenheim S&P 500 Pure Growth (RPG) for broad and well-diversified exposure to large-cap stocks.Growth investing and value investing are generally seen as being in favor in alternating periods. But the "Pure Growth" and "Pure Value" strategies have the potential to outperform at the same time, according to Guggenheim."The combination of both might be an attractive core position as opposed to one that's more tactically oriented," Belden said.It's worth noting that all six Guggenheim's "Pure Style" ETFs ranked in the 100 top-performing nonleveraged ETFs in this current bull market.Image at top provided by Shutterstock.

Electricity provider NRG Energy (NRG) and coal producer Consol Energy (CNX) became the latest energy companies to scale back their dividends on Monday amid a massive commodity-price slump, while Signet Jewelers (SIG) raised its own dividend.Consol said that it would suspend its regular quarterly dividend after completing a $420 million deal to sell its Buchanan mine in Virginia and other coal reserves. The sale of those assets, to coal producer Coronado IV, is expected to close in the first quarter.The moves will help Consol pay off debt and are intended "to further reflect the company's increased emphasis on growth," a Consol press release said.Consol shares closed up 10.1% in the stock market today.NRG Energy cut its yearly dividend by 12 cents a share to 58 cents per share after reporting a $6.4 billion net loss for last year.The dividend reduction "will allow NRG to reallocate approximately $145 million annually and provides additional flexibility to create shareholder value through all commodity, credit and development cycles and seize market opportunities," the company said.NRG shares closed down 2.7%.Many companies in the energy and mining sector have pulled back on dividend payouts to prop up their finances following years of debt-financed expansion when commodity prices were higher.Oil and gas producer Chesapeake Energy (CHK) said last month that it had suspended its quarterly preferred stock dividends, following similar plans from Linn Energy (LINE) and affiliate Linn (LNCO), announced last year, to suspend payouts.Signet Jewelers, meanwhile, OK'd an 18% boost in its quarterly cash dividend, to 26 cents per share from 22, for fiscal 2017's first quarter.Signet shares gapped up more than 9% after the company issued strong preliminary fourth-quarter results.

The First Solar (FSLR) and SunPower (SPWR) yieldco, 8point3 Energy Partners (CAFD), is aptly named on two counts.It takes 8.3 minutes for sunlight to hit the Earth. And the company's ticker was coined for its key performance metric: Cash Available For Distribution (CAFD), 8point3 CEO and SunPower CFO Chuck Boynton told IBD on Thursday.The ticker "differentiates us -- this vehicle is all about returning capital to our shareholders," Boynton said. "It's all about generating cash flow. The key thing to think about with CAFD is long-term sustainable distribution growth."Late Wednesday, 8point3 blew that metric out of the water, in its fiscal Q4 earnings report. In afternoon trading on the stock market today, 8point3 stock was up 6%, near 15.50.But shares are down 9% for the year, and 8point3 was part of the yieldco downtrend in 2015 that also slammed Terraform Power, Terraform Global and NRG Yield. 8point3 stock began trading in June at 21, and closed the year 23% off its IPO price.For its fiscal Q4 ended Nov. 30, 8point3 reported $16.3 million CAFD, up 143% sequentially and beating the high-end of the company's guidance by $1.1 billion.Revenue of $4 million rose 29% sequentially but missed the consensus of 12 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $5.2 million, and also missed the company's guidance for $4.9 million to $5.1 million.During Q4, 8point3 distributed 22 cents per share, up 3.5% sequentially and in line with guidance.For the current quarter, 8point3 sees $14.5 million to $15.5 million CAFD, $6 million to $7 million in sales and another 22 cents distribution per share. Sequentially, CAFD would be down 8% and sales would be up 62.5% at the midpoints of guidance. The sales guide missed expectations for $11.3 million.8point3's fiscal Q1 will always be its smallest CAFD quarter, Boynton said."December is the Winter Solstice, which is the shortest day of the year," he said. "So our revenues rise and fall with the sun. ... The winter quarter is roughly 10% of the annual yield, so there is definitely seasonality to solar."As a yield company, 8point3's objective is to generate free cash flow for shareholder distributions, Boynton said. The yieldco is structured so that distributions are tax-free until after a shareholder sells the stock.Wall Street is still coming around to the idea, he said. It's definitely not a day-trader's game, he says."Some investors really understand why solar is lower risk (but) it's not really into Wall Street yet," he said. "You put solar out there and it performs, it has very low risk. ... You typically don't have a lot of variability with the sun; it's not like the wind."IBD's 22-company Energy-Solar industry group closed 2015 up 1%, but suffered peaks and valleys as Congress debated the Investment Tax Credit on solar and states tackled the net-metering issue. Although Congress extended the ITC in an 11th-hour deal, Nevada and Hawaii shut down their net-metering programs. SolarCity (SCTY) and Sunrun (RUN) exited Nevada.Oil prices, although unrelated to solar wares, played a part too, Boynton said."In times like this when oil prices are down and volatility is up, I think investors have been running for cover," he said. "Over time, they will see it really is a safe haven and that of the companies that are yield-oriented we are at the top of the class."Shares of SunEdison's (SUNE) Terraform Power (TERP) and Terraform Global (GLBL), and NRG Energy's (NRG) NRG Yield (NYLD) exited 2015 slightly more haggard than 8point3 stock. Terraform Power stock closed the year down 57%, Terraform Global fell 63% off its IPO price and NRG Yield sliced 40% off its IPO.Boynton credits 8point3's dual sponsorship for its performance. During Q4, 8point3 completed its first drop-down project acquisition, a 20-megawatt Kern County School District project. The company's 432-MW initial portfolio is expected to generate $70 million in annual CAFD over the average 22-year contract term."With two sponsors, we really don't have to raise money," he said. "We have a very conservative structure and two sponsors who have long and distinctive track records."

Why? The reason for the forecast cut is that in a last-minute accord among politicians in December, Congress extended the Investment Tax Credit (ITC) on solar installations through…
Stock futures steered deep into the red Tuesday as investors continued to exit energy issues and show no tolerance for company earnings and operational slip-ups.

Dow futures veered 135.5 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures nosed down 41.5 points. S&P 500 futures unspooled 16 points. Small caps were taking hard early hits, sending Russell 2000 futures down 9 points.
The stock market today again gets only a small dose of economic news. The Labor Department delivers its Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey at 10 a.m. ET.

Oil futures were mixed early Tuesday, with Brent crude up, West Texas Intermediate down a fraction after diving nearly 6% each — to multiyear lows — on Monday. The dollar eased vs. the euro after a firm advance on Monday, holding well below Thursday's high.

Metal and mining issues were under some serious early pressure after U.K.-based Anglo American announced a stringent restructuring plan and also eliminated its dividend for the remainder of 2015 and all of 2016.
Anglo shares dived nearly 10% on the London Stock Exchange. ArcelorMittal (MT), Rio Tinto (RIO), BHP Billiton (BHP) and Vale (VALE) all fell 6% to 7% in premarket action.
Dow stocks were in a foul mood, nearly all trading lower, with Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) again diving deepest, down almost 2% apiece.
Energy-related issues also posted most of the worst losses among S&P 500 stocks. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) sank to the bottom of the list, down more than 5%.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) continued to lose value, down 5% on news reports of 28 Boston College students and facility staff falling ill after eating at one of the restaurants. The stock ended Monday down 27% since Oct. 13.
Power utility NRG (NRG) rose 3%, the S&P 500's top premarket gain. The stock is rebounding from a 22% tumble last week after long-time Chief Executive David Crane suddenly resigned.
Quarterly reports had slowed to a trickle, but still figured into early action.
Kids apparel retailer Children's Place (PLCE) jumped 5% after a mixed third-quarter report.
Redbox movie rental kiosk owner Outerwall (OUTR) tumbled 22% after management lowered its full-year 2015 EPS and revenue guidance to well below analyst consensus views.

The company also said President Mark Horak was resigning and that Chief Executive Erik Prusch would act also as interim president. Outerwall shares last week stumbled out of an attempt to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Organic distributor United Natural Foods (UNFI) toppled 11% after weak fiscal Q1 results.

Leaders on both the IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review lists were divided, with more down than up. Pre-opening gains were fractional for Hawaiian (HA) and LinkedIn (LNKD). The hardest hit IBD 50 stocks was Universal Display (OLED), down a bit less than 3%. Universal has been running into resistance as its fights to clear a 55.93 buy point in a deep cup base.

Stocks rallied across much of the session Friday, as a strong November jobs report overpowered a sharp pullback in oil prices and many energy stocks. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 both popped 2.1%. Preliminary data showed those moves carrying in weak trade.The gains took back the losses from Thursday, triggered by a disappointing monetary policy decision from the European Central Bank.For the week, the results left the Nasdaq up 0.3%, while the S&P 500 was a fraction higher and back above its 200-day moving average.Before the open, the Labor Department's payroll report showed a bigger-than-expected jump in November payrolls, backing views that the economy is on an even and mending keel, appearing to clear the path for a Fed rate hike at the Dec. 15-16 meeting.The Dow ended Friday up 2.1%, unanimously positive. Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Home Depot (HD) topped the index, each with 3% gains.Gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM) led the S&P 500, up more than 9%. Troubled utility NRG (NRG) staked out the index's low end with an 18% decline.Among leaders, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) easily topped the IBD 50 list, surging 13% after posting strong Q3 results late Thursday. The gap-up gain snapped shares past an early 175.88 buy point in a three-month base. The stock ended less than 5% above the entry.Fellow IBD 50 stock Alaska Air (ALK) soared 5% in fast trade, marking a new high. The stock is still in buy range from the 82.88 buy point of a late-stage flat base initially cleared Wednesday. Hawaiian (HA) lifted 3%.China-based NetEase (NTES) also rocketed 5%, seizing a fresh high and ending 16% past a 154.62 buy point.Among new issues, Fitbit (FIT) jumped into action with a 10% surge in twice the usual pace. It rallied 14% for the week as it continues to move off its Nov. 23 intraday low. Fitbit shipped 4.7 million units worldwide in Q3 to remain the top vendor of wearables, which include smartwatches and fitness tracking devices, according to an IDC report released Thursday.For next week, the earnings calendar continues to lighten, with United Natural Foods (UNFI), Mattress Firm (MFRM), H&R Block (HRB) and HealthEquity (HQY) scheduled to report Monday. The economic calendar also gets a quiet start, with a speech by St. Louis Fed President James Bullard marking the high point for day.
Stocks stumbled in mixed trade for a second straight morning Wednesday, as global markets reacted to monetary policy actions by the European Central Bank.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average sat flat, while the S&P 500 and Russell 2000 each dipped 0.1%.
The stock market today again opened to mixed volume, with trade rising 9% on the NYSE and declining fractionally on the Nasdaq, vs. action at the same time Wednesday.

Before the open, U.S. stock futures had appeared to feel some premarket drag from Europe's bourses, which reversed sharply from moderate gains after the European Central Bank announced it would further reduce its overnight deposit rate to -0.3%, from -0.2%.
The move was less than what many had been led to expect by previous comments from ECB President Mario Draghi and other officials.

Europe's markets did not improve when, in a later press conference, Draghi said the bank would extend its current bond buying initiative to March 2017 or longer if necessary, vs. the prior endpoint of September 2016.
Frankfurt's DAX dropped 2.7%. The Cac-40 in Paris was down 2.9%, and outside the eurozone, the FTSE 100 in London slipped 1.9% in afternoon trade.
Layoffs fell to a 14-month low in November, consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported, and weekly jobless claims rose, but in line with the consensus forecast.
Factory orders strengthened 1.5% in October, the Commerce Department said, up from a 0.8% slip in September and better than the 1.4% improvement expected by analysts.

The Institute for Supply Management said growth in the services portion of the economy slowed in November, with its ISM Services index falling to 55.9, down from October's 59.1 reading. Analysts had forecast a smaller pullback, to 58.2.

Dow stocks turned negative after the open, with more than two-thirds of the 30-stock index posting losses. Merck (MRK) and American Express (AXP) took the biggest bumps, down about 1% apiece. Gains were thin, led by Wal-Mart's (WMT) 1.6% advance.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) spiked more than 10% to the top of both the IBD 50 list and the S&P 500, following its fiscal-fourth-quarter results reported late Wednesday. Research firms Mizuho and Topeka Capital both raised their price targets on the stock Thursday morning.
The gain left Avago shares well up the right side of a five-month cup base, below a 150.60 buy point.

Biotech Dyax (DYAX) vaulted 12% higher, as the company announced the early termination of the anti-trust waiting period regarding its pending $5.9 billion acquisition by Ireland-based Shire (SHPG). Shire dipped 1.9% at the open.

Utilities were unusually active at the start of trade, with NRG (NRG) rising nearly 8% after President and Chief Executive David Crane tendered his immediate resignation, though the shares later lost most of the gain to trade almost flat. Chief Operating Officer Mauricio Gutierrez will step into the role.
The power producer on Tuesday announced plans to sell two power plants in Pennsylvania and Illinois for a total of $138 million. NRG has been in a deepening correction for 17 months.

First Solar (FSLR) stock was up 17% in afternoon trading Wednesday as analysts trumpeted the solar panel maker's "across the board" second-quarter beat. In Q2, First Solar nearly tripled Wall Street's per-share earnings forecast and posted $896 million in revenue, up 65% from the year-earlier quarter and well ahead of analyst views of $752 million. At least three analysts upped…

Canadian Solar (CSIQ) stock plunged 18% Wednesday after the solar panel maker revealed late Tuesday that market "volatility" might force the company to abandon its yieldco spinoff plans.The company also guided down for Q3, citing resources that may need to be held back should the yieldco ultimately launch. The yieldco is on track for late 2015 or early 2016, CEO Shawn Qu said during the Q2 earnings conference call.If its yieldco advances, Canadian Solar will join the ranks of several solar companies that have already done such dividend growth-oriented spinoffs that hold operating assets, including SunEdison (SUNE), NRG Energy (NRG), First Solar (FSLR) and SunPower (SPWR).SunEdison was first to the yieldco model with its TerraForm Power (TERP) in July 2014. NRG followed with NRG Yield (NYLD) in May. First Solar and SunPower teamed up to create 8point3 Energy Partners (CAFD) in June.During Canadian Solar's Q2 earnings conference call, CFO Michael Potter acknowledged the volatility surrounding the yieldco market. In general, TerraForm, NRG Yield and 8point3 shares have largely declined since their IPOs."We recognize that the market has recently experienced volatility around yieldco valuation," he said. "As such we have alternative plans in place to a yieldco, if needed, to monetize our utility-scale solar power plant assets."In lieu of a yieldco, Potter said, Canadian Solar could benefit from selling projects outright or finding a strategic partner.Mixed EarningsCanadian Solar's Q2 earnings were a mixed bag.In terms of revenue, the solar panel maker beat its year-earlier quarter and Wall Street's forecast with $636.7 million in sales, up 2% vs. Q2 2014.The company also announced earnings per share ex items of 31 cents, which beat the consensus forecast of 13 cents but fell short of the year-earlier quarter, when Canadian Solar posted 95 cents EPS.For Q3, Canadian Solar guided to a range of between $570 million to $620 million in revenue, which would be down 6.5% from Q2 at the midpoint.Analysts expressed concern over the floundering yieldco discussion.Canaccord analyst Jed Dorsheimer lowered his price target on Canadian Solar stock to 40 from 45 and reiterated a buy rating. Like Potter, he noted the notoriously volatile solar market and rivals' recently struggling yieldcos."The recent yieldco downward spiral does little to bolster sentiment or valuation around Canadian Solar's pending yieldco," he wrote in a research report. "In fact, we question whether current investor demand for yieldcos will be enough for the company to go to market with a yieldco."Paul Coster, a JPMorgan analyst, dropped his price target on Canadian Solar stock to 36 from 39 and reiterated his overweight rating. He, too, craved more information regarding the company's possible yieldco, which could "provide a catalyst."Canadian Solar stock closed at 20.20 Wednesday.Rival Trina Solar Also BeatsCanadian Solar rival Trina Solar (TSL) suffered a drop in the stock market today too. Trina Solar stock traded at a seven-month low, closing down 9% for the day at 9.40.Like Canadian Solar, Trina Solar bested Wall Street's forecast. In Q2, Trina Solar reported on Tuesday that it made $722.9 million in revenue, up 39.2% vs. Q2 2014. Earnings per American depositary share grew 200% from the year-earlier quarter to 42 cents, beating the consensus for 25 cents.Trina Solar didn't provide a financial outlook for Q3 but did hint that a downstream spinoff might be in the works. That spinoff would require a $1 billion investment, CFO Teresa Tan said during the Q2 earnings conference call.First, Trina Solar must weigh investors' interest, she said."We need to evaluate not only the appetite from the investor perspective, but also the future financing options and possibilities for our downstream business as well," she said.S&P Capital analyst Angelo Zino maintained his 17 price target on Trina Solar stock and reiterated his buy rating.Zino noted Trina Solar's robust demand in China and other Asia-Pacific countries. In Q2, a record high 37% of the company's volume shipped to China, Tan said."We look for global solar installations to increase at a modest pace and are encouraged by stabilization in module prices," Zino wrote in a research report. "TSL's aggressive pricing and increasing conversion efficiencies will lead to market share gains."However, Zino sees revenue growth slowing from 29% in 2014 to 16% in 2015 and down to 2.8% in 2016.Raymond James analyst Pavel Molchanov reiterated a market perform rating on Trina Solar stock, noting that "what Trina delivered is a textbook beat-and-raise."Still, he remained unsure of the profitability of Trina Solar's model."The main concern that we have about Trina — and more broadly, the commodity module arena — is that this remains ... a commoditized, low-margin business," he wrote in a research report. "Profitability metrics are choppy and not especially robust."Connect with Allison Gatlin: Twitter | Facebook.
SunEdison (SUNE) and Advanced Microgrid Solutions announced Wednesday a 50-megawatt solar energy storage deal that will supply power to Southern California Edison.
The utility-scale battery storage systems will be installed under a 10-year contract with Southern California Edison, one of the nation's largest utilities.

Advanced Microgrid Solutions will develop storage systems in commercial and industrial buildings. Southern California Edison will use the battery storage systems to help shift electrical load during peak times. The utility also will use the electricity stored in the buildings to partially offset power once produced by the decommissioned San Onofre nuclear power plant and other soon-to-be retired gas-fired plants, SunEdison said.
Battery storage of solar energy is starting to make economic sense for utilities, if not yet for homeowners.
The initial energy storage systems are expected to begin commercial operation next year in Irvine, Calif.
SunEdison stock, however, was down 1.5% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 31. SunEdison stock touched a near seven-year high of 32.66 on June 30.

Once operational, the solar energy storage systems will be acquired by SunEdison's yield company, TerraForm Power (TERP), making them the first solar storage projects in its fleet, TerraForm Power CEO Carlos Domenech said in a press release.

"These systems fit well with our contracted clean-power generation fleet, as they have long-term capacity contracts with Southern California Edison, a leading utility and customer with a strong balance sheet and credit rating," Domenech said.

This month, SunEdison and TerraForm Power announced they're acquiring a portfolio of wind power plants from Invenergy Wind in a deal valued at $2 billion. The portfolio includes seven wind farms in the U.S. and Canada. Invenergy plans to retain a 9.9% stake in the U.S. wind farms and will provide some operation and maintenance services.
Others Form Yieldcos

Solar firms and other energy companies such as NRG Energy (NRG) are forming "yield companies" to own and operate assets such as power plants that generate dividends for investors based on long-term electricity contracts and can provide funding to finance new projects.

SunEdison has announced it plans to form TerraForm Global, its second yieldco, to own and operate renewable-energy power plants in emerging markets. In May, SunEdison said it plans to raise as much as $700 million in an initial public offering for TerraForm Global.

In a separate announcement Wednesday, solar financing companies Clean Power Finance and Kilowatt Financial announced they plan to merge into a new company called Elevate Power. It will offer loans, leases and power-purchase agreements. In a joint press release, the companies said Nat Kreamer will serve as CEO of the new company, which will have more than $1.6 billion in project and loan financing under management and be able to finance solar in 46 states.SunEdison (SUNE) and Advanced Microgrid Solutions announced Wednesday a 50-megawatt solar energy storage deal that will supply power to Southern California Edison.The utility-scale battery storage systems will be installed under a 10-year contract with Southern California Edison, one of the nation's largest utilities.Advanced Microgrid Solutions will develop storage systems in commercial and industrial buildings. Crude oil's six-month price dive through January and the ongoing U.S. oversupply of cheap natural gas failed to make a significant dent in the outlooks of several companies in the alternative energy industry. Oil's volatility over the last two months, including a steep dive in the past week, has finally begun to chew into the stock charts of some renewables.…

The yieldco 8point3 Energy Partners LP, formed by solar energy kingpins First Solar (FSLR) and SunPower (SPWR), is expected to raise approximately $420 million in an initial public offering scheduled to begin trading Friday.
Tempe, Ariz.-based solar module maker First Solar and San Jose, Calif.-based solar panel and system maker SunPower announced in February they would form the yield company, or "yieldco."

A yieldco is a publicly traded subsidiary that owns and operates power-generating assets to produce revenue from long-term contracts to sell electricity to utilities and issue regular dividends to shareholders. First Solar and SunPower will retain a significant stake in the yieldco, which can provide capital to fund new projects at lower rates than the complex tax-equity investments and bank debt now commonly used in the solar industry.
The solar companies expect to sell 20 million shares at 19 to 21, for their joint yieldco called 8point3 Energy Partners. The yieldco will be listed on the Nasdaq under the symbol CAFD.
The yieldco will have about 432 megawatts of solar projects in its portfolio, including 262 MW of utility-scale projects from First Solar and 170 MW of utility and other projects from SunPower.

First Solar and SunPower executives have said the yieldco will help them fund new projects, lower the overall cost of capital and potentially improve the valuation of their respective project development businesses.

8Point3 Energy Partners — it takes 8.3 minutes for light from the sun to reach the earth, hence the name — will pay out an initial quarterly distribution of $0.2097 per Class A share, which translates into an annualized yield of about 4.2%. 8Point3 Energy is targeting an annual growth rate of distributions of 12% to 15% per Class A share over the three-year period following completion of its offering.
TerraForm Power (TERP), a yieldco spun off of solar installer SunEdison (SUNE), made its IPO in July at 25 and closed Tuesday near 39.
NRG Energy (NRG) was an early player in the yieldco trend, spinning off a mix of conventional power plants and wind and solar farms as NRG Yield (NYLD).

Global solar demand is expected to grow by about 30% this year to 57 GW, according to market research firm IHS. U.S. demand is projected remain strong through 2016, as installers take advantage of the federal 30% investment tax credit for residential and commercial solar projects. At the end of 2016, the tax credit is scheduled to drop to 10% for commercial and expire entirely for residential solar projects.

IBD's Energy-Solar industry group ranks No. 11 out of 197 groups tracked. SunPower stock was up 26% this year through Tuesday, while First Solar stock was up 17%, but they are 23% and 30%, respectively, off from six-year highs touched last year.

First Solar and SunPower's preparations for their joint yield company looked rockier than anticipated Thursday as both reported surprisingly steep first-quarter sales declines. The two largest U.S. solar panel makers are selling fewer power plants so they can retain some assets for their new venture. As a result, analysts were expecting sales drops — but not as steep as what was reported.

Tempe, Ariz.-based First Solar  (FSLR) swung to a loss of 62 cents per share from a profit of $1.10 per share a year ago, missing analysts' views for a 29-cent per-share loss. Revenue plunged 51% to $469.21 million, below the consensus of $599.5 million.

But First Solar sees Q2 earnings per share of 45-55 cents, including a non-recurring tax benefit of approximately 40 cents. Analysts see EPS of 40 cents. First Solar also sees Q2 sales of $750 million-$850 million, with the midpoint above the $779.7 million consensus.
Shares fell 4.5% in late trading after closing down 3.7%.

San Jose, Calif.-based SunPower (SPWR) earned 13 cents a share excluding items, down 73.5% from a year earlier but above views by 4 cents. Non-GAAP revenue fell 37% to $430.6 million, missing views of $452.6 million.
Shares dropped 4.8% in late trading after closing down 3.3%.
In February, First Solar and SunPower announced plans to jointly form a publicly traded yieldco, a vehicle used by some energy companies that is similar to a real estate investment trust.

The yieldco will own and operate solar-power projects to generate revenue to be paid out as dividends to investors. The companies could use capital generated from the yieldco to fund new power projects.

The First Solar-SunPower yieldco will join others in the sector. SunEdison (SUNE) formed TerraForm Power (TERP), which had an IPO in July. NRG Energy (NRG) and NextEra Energy Partners (NEP) have also established one.

Meanwhile, SunPower is also looking for more overseas business and said in mid-April that it's partnering with Apple (AAPL) on China solar power projects totaling 40 megawatts.First Solar and SunPower's preparations for their joint yield company looked rockier than anticipated Thursday as both reported surprisingly steep first-quarter sales declines.
